title: GT &shortversion; RLS: System Administrator's Guide

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This guide contains advanced configuration information for system administrators working with RLS. It provides references to information on procedures typically performed by system administrators, including installation, configuring, deploying, and testing the installation.

important.simpara: This information is in addition to the basic Globus Toolkit prerequisite, overview, installation, security configuration instructions in the . Read through this guide before continuing!

section.title: Building and Installing
section.para: RLS is built and installed as part of a default GT 4.0 installation. When installing RLS from binary bundles, the RLS has been linked against the iODBC library. Building RLS from source requires that a suitable ODBC manager library (either iODBC or unixODBC) be configured. Without it, the RLS server installation will be skipped.

important.para: The RLS depends on third party database management systems (DBMS) and Open Database Connectivity libraries (ODBC). If you are not familiar with DBMS and ODBC software, please invest the time to familiarize yourself with these tools before proceeding with RLS installation. Most of the difficulty users experience when installing RLS is actually due to DBMS and ODBC issues.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: The RLS depends on an ODBC manager. The unixODBC or iODBC libraries may be used for this purpose. Please confirm that one of these libraries is installed and configured before proceeding with RLS installation. If you need more information on the ODBC managers, please consult their respective project home pages.

You may also find that unixODBC or (less likely) libiodbc are included along with a vendor's odbc driver. This appears to be the case with MySQL Connector/ODBC drivers at the time of writing this document.

note.para: Please consult the above sites for authoritative information on unixODBC and iODBC. Any information provided on this site is intended as helpful advise and only relfects our limited experiences as fellow users of the software.

If you build from source, be aware that some versions of a vendor's drivers do not build against some versions of the same vendor's clients. For instance, MySQL Connector/ODBC 3.51.06 does not appear to build againt MySQL 4.1.x client libraries, instead it requires MySQL 4.0.x client libraries. Also, we have noticed that psqlodbc-07.03.x will build against pgsql-7.4.x but when using the driver it fails with little or no information to indicate why it failed. We have found that psqlodbc-08.00.x works well with postgres-7.4.6. In all cases, consult the vendor's documentation.
